questions.text: The most common leukocytoclastic vasculitis affecting children is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP). Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP) is the most common form of leukocytoclastic vasculitis in children. It is a small-vessel vasculitis that is characterized by purpura, particularly on the lower extremities, abdominal pain, arthralgia, and sometimes renal involvement (glomerulonephritis). HSP is most commonly seen in children aged 2-11 years and often follows an upper respiratory tract infection. The condition is typically self-limited, but it can lead to complications, particularly renal involvement, which may require monitoring. Explanation of incorrect responses: A. Takayasu disease: Takayasu arteritis is a large-vessel vasculitis that primarily affects young women, and it is much less common in children. It typically involves the aorta and its major branches, causing vascular inflammation and narrowing, which leads to symptoms such as claudication, hypertension, and ischemia. It is not the most common vasculitis in children. B. Mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome (Kawasaki disease): Kawasaki disease is a medium-vessel vasculitis that primarily affects children under the age of 5. It is characterized by fever, conjunctivitis, rash, swollen lymph nodes, and coronary artery aneurysms. While it is an important vasculitis in children, it is not classified as a leukocytoclastic vasculitis, and HSP remains more common in the pediatric population. D. Polyarteritis nodosa: Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a rare vasculitis affecting medium- and small-sized arteries, typically in adults but can occasionally affect children. It is less common than HSP in children and involves systemic inflammation of the vessels, which can lead to organ damage and a variety of systemic symptoms, including abdominal pain, muscle and joint pain, and kidney involvement.

choices.text: Failure to make patient afebrile despite 2 courses of IVIG

questions.text: Indication of Prednisolone in Kawasaki disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Failure to make patient afebrile despite 2 courses of IVIG. Prednisolone (a corticosteroid) is used in the management of Kawasaki disease in specific situations, particularly when there is a failure to achieve defervescence (fever resolution) after two courses of intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG). Despite the initial standard treatment with IVIG, if the child continues to have fever for more than 36 hours after the second dose, prednisolone is often added to reduce inflammation and prevent further complications, such as coronary artery damage. Explanation of incorrect responses: A. Giant coronary aneurysms: The presence of giant coronary aneurysms is a severe complication of Kawasaki disease, and while it is important to monitor and manage these patients closely, corticosteroids like prednisolone are not typically used solely for the treatment of aneurysms. IVIG and aspirin are the mainstays of treatment to reduce the risk of coronary artery abnormalities. B. Age 50/hr: While thrombocytosis (elevated platelet count) and elevated ESR (erythrocyte sedimentation rate) are common findings in Kawasaki disease, they are not direct indications for the use of prednisolone. The treatment decision is more focused on managing the fever and inflammation, which is why failure to resolve the fever with IVIG (option D) is a key factor in deciding to add prednisolone.

questions.text: What is the recurrence rate of Kawasaki disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 1-3%. Kawasaki disease (KD) is a rare condition, and while most children who receive appropriate treatment (such as intravenous immunoglobulin and aspirin) do well, a small percentage can experience a recurrence of the disease. The recurrence rate of Kawasaki disease is generally low, typically around 1-3% of children who have had the disease. Explanation of incorrect options: A. 0-1%: The recurrence rate is slightly higher than this, and 0-1% would underestimate the true recurrence rate of the condition. C. 3-10%: While this range is somewhat close, it overestimates the recurrence rate. Research generally places the recurrence rate closer to 1-3%. D. 10-35%: This would be an unusually high estimate for recurrence and is not consistent with the known statistics for Kawasaki disease.

questions.text: Most common type of juvenile idiopathic arthritis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Oligoarticular. Oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is the most common form of juvenile arthritis, accounting for about 50-60% of cases. This type of JIA typically affects 4 or fewer joints in the first 6 months of the disease. It primarily involves the large joints such as the knees and hips, and often has a better prognosis compared to other types. Explanation of incorrect options: A. Polyarticular: Polyarticular JIA affects 5 or more joints and is less common than oligoarticular JIA. It tends to have a more aggressive course and can involve both small and large joints, often leading to more complications. B. Enthesitis-related: This type involves inflammation at the sites where tendons or ligaments attach to bones (entheses). It is less common and often associated with HLA-B27 positivity, typically affecting the lower limbs and sometimes the spine. D. Systemic-onset JIA: Systemic-onset JIA, also known as Still's disease, is the least common type of JIA and is characterized by systemic symptoms such as fever, rash, and organ involvement (e.g., liver, spleen). It is more severe but rare compared to the other types.

questions.text: Henoch-schonlein purpura commonly involves which age group?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • Henoch schonlein purpura is most commonly seen in young children between 3 to 10 years of age. • It is rare to see HSP below 1 year or above 20 years, although some cases have been reported.According to Nelson 20th Ed, “approximately 90% of HSP cases occur in children, usually between the ages of 3 and 10 yr. HSP is distinctly less common in adults, in whom severe and chronic complications are often encountered.”

questions.text: A 2 year old child was diagnosed as having Kawasaki disease and was given IVIG in a dose of 2 g/kg. 36 hr later, the child continues to be febrile and has significant conjunctival and mucosal erythema. What next needs to be done?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) • The patient has IVIG-resistant KD, whichoccurs in approximately 15% of patients and is defined by persistent or recrudescent fever 36 hr after completion of the initial IVIG infusion. Patients with IVIG resistance are at increased risk for CAA. • Typically, another dose of IVIG at 2 g/kg is administered to patients with IVIG resistance. Corticosteroids in varying doses and via different routes have also been used as secondary or “rescue” therapy when fever persists after the first IVIG. • Tumor necrosis factor inhibitors, including infliximab and etanercept, have also been given for the treatment of IVIG-resistant disease in steroid non-responsive cases.

Correct Answer (D) Thrombocytopenia. Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a type of leukocytoclastic vasculitis that commonly affects children and is characterized by the following key features: Purpura: The hallmark of HSP, often seen on the buttocks, lower legs, and sometimes on the arms. Renal involvement: HSP frequently causes glomerulonephritis, which can lead to hematuria and proteinuria. Arthritis: Joint involvement is common, particularly affecting the knees and ankles. However, thrombocytopenia is not typically seen in HSP. In fact, platelet counts are usually normal in this condition. Thrombocytopenia would suggest another diagnosis, such as idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) or disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Explanation of incorrect options: A. Purpura on buttocks: This is a classic feature of HSP, and the purpura often appears in areas of dependent circulation like the buttocks and lower limbs. B. Renal involvement: This is a common complication in HSP, with hematuria and proteinuria being the most frequent renal manifestations. C. Arthritis: Joint involvement is common in HSP, typically affecting the knees and ankles, and is usually self-limiting.

choices.text: Erythematous changes in the oral mucosa

questions.text: All of the following are features to diagnose Kawasaki disease, except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Myocarditis. Kawasaki disease is a vasculitis that primarily affects children and leads to inflammation of the blood vessels, including the coronary arteries. The diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease are primarily based on the presence of fever and several characteristic clinical features. The features used for diagnosis include: B. High fever lasting at least 5 days: One of the hallmark features of Kawasaki disease is a high fever lasting for at least 5 days. This is often the first and most prominent symptom of the disease. C. Desquamation and rash: A rash often appears during the acute phase of the disease, typically involving the trunk and extremities. Desquamation (peeling of the skin) often occurs on the fingers, toes, and around the nail beds during the convalescent phase. D. Erythematous changes in the oral mucosa: These include redness and inflammation of the lips, tongue (often described as "strawberry tongue"), and oral mucosa, along with cracking of the lips.

questions.text: Drug of choice in Kawasaki disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) IVIG (Intravenous Immunoglobulin). Intravenous Immunoglobulin (IVIG) is the first-line treatment for Kawasaki disease and is used to reduce the risk of coronary artery complications, particularly coronary artery aneurysms, which are a major concern in this condition. IVIG is administered in a high dose (2 g/kg) over a period of 8-12 hours. It is most effective when given within the first 10 days of illness, ideally as early as possible to reduce the risk of long-term cardiovascular complications. Incorrect options: A. Prednisolone: While corticosteroids like prednisolone are sometimes used as an adjunctive therapy in resistant cases, they are not the first-line treatment for Kawasaki disease. In fact, IVIG is preferred over steroids for initial treatment. C. Rituximab: Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody used for certain autoimmune diseases, but it is not the standard treatment for Kawasaki disease. It may be considered in refractory cases, but it is not routinely used. D. Infliximab: Infliximab is an anti-TNF-alpha monoclonal antibody that is used in some autoimmune diseases like Crohn’s disease and rheumatoid arthritis, but it is not a standard treatment for Kawasaki disease.

questions.text: Incidence of coronary artery aneurysms in untreated Kawasaki disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 15-25%. In untreated Kawasaki disease, coronary artery aneurysms occur in approximately 15-25% of cases. These aneurysms are a serious complication of Kawasaki disease and can lead to significant long-term cardiovascular issues, including myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, and even death in severe cases. Early diagnosis and treatment with intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) significantly reduce the risk of these complications. Incorrect options: A. <5%: This is an underestimate of the incidence of coronary artery aneurysms in untreated Kawasaki disease. The risk is much higher in untreated cases. B. 5-10%: Although the risk of coronary artery aneurysms is lower with early treatment, untreated cases are more likely to experience a higher incidence (closer to 15-25%). D. 40-60%: This represents a very high risk and is not typical of untreated Kawasaki disease. Such high rates of coronary artery aneurysms are more likely to occur in severe cases or in those with inadequate treatment.

questions.text: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis of systemic onset variety, all are seen except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) • sJIAis characterized by arthritis, fever, rash, and prominent visceralinvolvement, including hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, andserositis (pericarditis). • The characteristic fever, defined as spiking temperaturesto ?39°C (102.2°F), occurs on a daily or twice-daily basis forat least 2 wk, with a rapid return to normal or subnormal temperatures. • The fever is often present in the evening and is frequentlyaccompanied by a characteristic faint, erythematous, macular rash. • Theevanescent salmon-colored lesions, classic for sJIA, are linear or circularand are most commonly distributed over the trunk and proximalextremities. • The classic rash is nonpruritic and migratorywith lesions lasting 70% of affected children.

questions.text: A 5 years old child presents with perivascular IgA deposition and neutrophilic collection. There is erythematous rash on the lower limbs and non-blanching purpura. Probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Henoch-Schönlein purpura. Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a small vessel vasculitis that primarily affects children. It is characterized by the deposition of IgA in the affected vessels and the accumulation of neutrophils. Key features of HSP include: Purpuric rash: Typically affects the lower limbs and may appear as non-blanching purpura. Abdominal pain: Often due to mesenteric vasculitis. Arthritis: Especially in larger joints. Renal involvement: Hematuria and proteinuria can occur. The perivascular IgA deposition and the neutrophilic collection described are classic findings for HSP. Incorrect options: B. Wegener’s granulomatosis: This is a type of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) and typically affects the respiratory tract and kidneys. It is characterized by granulomatous inflammation and necrotizing vasculitis, but not by perivascular IgA deposition. C. Cryoglobulinemia: This is a condition characterized by the presence of cryoglobulins in the blood, leading to symptoms such as purpura and vasculitis, but the rash and pathophysiology do not fit as well with the description in this case. D. Kawasaki disease: Kawasaki disease involves inflammation of medium-sized arteries, with prominent features such as fever, rash, conjunctivitis, and oral mucosal changes. It does not typically involve perivascular IgA deposition or neutrophilic collection.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in Henoch schonlein purpura?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) • Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is the most common small vesselvasculitis in childhood.Kawasaki disease is the most common vasculitis in childhood. • It is characterized by a purpuric rash and commonlyaccompanied by arthritis and abdominal pain. • Approximately 50% of patients with HSP develop renal manifestations,which vary from asymptomatic microscopic hematuria tosevere, progressive glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: Which immunoglobulin gets deposited perivascularly in HSP?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) IgA. In Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), IgA is the immunoglobulin that is deposited in the perivascular regions of affected blood vessels. The IgA deposition in small vessels is a hallmark of the disease and leads to the characteristic features of HSP, such as the purpuric rash, arthritis, abdominal pain, and renal involvement. Incorrect options: A. IgM: This is associated with cold agglutinin disease and some viral infections, but not typically with HSP. B. IgG: This is involved in other immune complex-mediated diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus, but it is not the primary immunoglobulin in HSP. D. IgD: This immunoglobulin is involved in the immune response but does not play a role in the pathophysiology of HSP.

questions.text: The most common causative agent in plant thorn synovitis in children is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) • A diagnosis of plant thorn synovitis should be considered in childrenwith monoarticular arthritis nonresponsive to anti-inflammatory therapy. • Acute or chronic arthritis can occur after a plant thorn orother foreign object penetrates a joint. Unlike septic arthritis, childrenwith plant thorn synovitis are commonly afebrile. • The most commonorganism seen with plant thorn synovitis is Pantoeaagglomerans,although cultures are often negative.

questions.text: Most common type of scleroderma in childhood is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Morphea. Morphea is the most common type of scleroderma in children. It is a localized form of scleroderma characterized by the development of hard, thickened patches of skin, typically on the trunk, arms, or legs. Unlike systemic scleroderma, morphea does not usually involve internal organs and remains confined to the skin. Incorrect options: A. Diffuse systemic: This form of scleroderma involves widespread skin thickening and can affect internal organs, such as the heart, lungs, and kidneys. It is less common in children compared to morphea. C. Bullous: Bullous scleroderma refers to the formation of blisters, which is not a typical feature of scleroderma and is less common in children. D. Pansclerotic: This is a rare and severe form of scleroderma that involves thickening of the skin and tissues all over the body and can also affect internal organs. It is not the most common type in childhood.

questions.text: In HSP, renal involvement can occur upto what time of diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Within 6 months. Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP) is a systemic vasculitis primarily affecting children, and it can lead to renal involvement, which typically manifests as hematuria or proteinuria. Renal complications in HSP can occur up to 6 months after the initial diagnosis, and in some cases, they may even appear later. Most cases of renal involvement occur during the acute phase, but it's important to monitor for renal issues up to 6 months or longer, as the condition can have a delayed onset of kidney problems. Incorrect options: A. Within 1 month: Although renal involvement can appear early, it is more likely to occur within a longer time frame, typically up to 6 months, rather than just within 1 month. B. Within 2 months: While some renal complications can present within 2 months, the full range of renal issues in HSP may emerge later, closer to the 6-month mark. C. Within 4 months: Renal complications can appear within 4 months, but monitoring should continue up to 6 months, as renal issues may still arise in the latter part of the time window.

questions.text: Familial form of sarcoidosis shows which type of inheritance?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) AD (Autosomal Dominant). Sarcoidosis is a systemic inflammatory disease characterized by the formation of granulomas, primarily affecting the lungs but also involving other organs. While the exact cause of sarcoidosis is unknown, familial clustering suggests a genetic predisposition. The familial form of sarcoidosis follows an autosomal dominant (AD) inheritance pattern, meaning that having one affected parent can increase the likelihood of inheriting the disease. Studies have shown that genetic factors contribute significantly to the disease, and the autosomal dominant inheritance is most commonly seen in cases where multiple family members are affected. Incorrect options: A. AR (Autosomal Recessive): While some diseases show autosomal recessive inheritance, sarcoidosis typically does not follow this pattern. It is more likely to be inherited in an autosomal dominant manner in familial cases. C. XLD (X-linked Dominant): This type of inheritance involves genes located on the X chromosome. Sarcoidosis does not typically follow an X-linked dominant pattern of inheritance. D. XLR (X-linked Recessive): X-linked recessive inheritance usually affects males more severely, as they only have one X chromosome. Sarcoidosis is not linked to X-linked recessive inheritance.

choices.text: Desquamation after 2-3 weeks of disease onset

questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Fever lasting more than 4 weeks. Explanation: Kawasaki disease is an acute inflammatory condition that predominantly affects children and leads to systemic vasculitis. It typically presents with fever and other characteristic symptoms. However, the fever in Kawasaki disease does not last for more than 4 weeks. Fever lasting more than 4 weeks: This is not characteristic of Kawasaki disease. The fever in Kawasaki disease usually lasts for at least 5 days but resolves with appropriate treatment (such as intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG)) within a shorter duration. Prolonged fever lasting more than 4 weeks may suggest a different underlying condition. Incorrect options: B. Desquamation after 2-3 weeks of disease onset: This is a classic feature of Kawasaki disease. Desquamation (peeling of the skin) typically occurs after 2-3 weeks, especially in the periungual area (around the nails). C. Raised acute phase reactants: Elevated markers like C-reactive protein (CRP) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) are common in Kawasaki disease, indicating ongoing inflammation. D. High risk of cardiac complications: One of the major concerns in Kawasaki disease is the development of coronary artery aneurysms, which can lead to significant cardiac complications, including heart attacks. Thus, Kawasaki disease is associated with a high risk of cardiac complications.
